title: Quiz 6: January 2009 Licensure Exam (Paper Two)
description: Comprehensive review of the January 2009 Paper Two Licensure Examination, covering embryology, labour physiology, neonatal care, and obstetric emergencies.

questions.question: The trophoblast cells of the developing zygote differentiate to form which structures?
questions.explanation: The blastocyst separates into the inner cell mass (embryoblast - forms fetus/amnion) and the outer layer (trophoblast - forms placenta/chorion).

questions.question: Calculate the Expected Date of Delivery (EDD) if the Last Menstrual Period (LMP) was 27.7.08.
questions.explanation: Using Naegele's rule: 27 + 7 = 34 (which is 3rd of Aug). July (7) - 3 months = April (4). Since days spilled over to next month, Month becomes May (5). Year = 09. Answer: 3rd May 2009.
questions.hint: Add 7 days first, then count back 3 months.

questions.question: In focused antenatal care (IPTp), when is the second dose of Sulfadoxine Pyrimethamine (SP) typically administered?
questions.explanation: The second dose is given at least one month after the first, typically in the early third trimester (28-34 weeks).

questions.question: What range of increase in diastolic blood pressure (mmHg) is considered significant in the assessment of Pre-eclampsia?
questions.explanation: A rise of 15 mmHg or more in diastolic pressure above baseline is a classic warning sign, though absolute values (>90) are also used.

questions.question: What is the appropriate management for Placenta Previa Type 3 when the fetus has died in utero?
questions.explanation: Type 3 (Major) Placenta Previa covers the os. Vaginal delivery is impossible and dangerous (hemorrhage) regardless of fetal status. C-section is mandatory to save the mother.
questions.hint: Safety of the mother is priority; vaginal route is blocked.

questions.question: Which hormonal factors are responsible for uterine contractions at the onset of labour?
questions.explanation: High Estrogen sensitizes the uterus to Oxytocin and Prostaglandins. Prostaglandins soften the cervix and stimulate contractions. Progesterone (the relaxant) withdrawal also plays a role.

questions.question: Fetal axis pressure is a physical force that becomes most significant during which stage?

options.text: Active/Second stage when membranes are ruptured
Early labor transmitting force to the lower pole of uterus

questions.explanation: When membranes rupture, the fundus contracts directly against the fetal breech, transmitting force down the fetal spine (axis) to the head, aiding descent and flexion.

questions.question: If membranes rupture at 8 cm dilation, a vaginal examination is performed immediately to rule out:
questions.explanation: The rush of fluid can wash the umbilical cord down in front of the head (Cord Prolapse), which is an acute emergency.

questions.question: On a partograph, good progress in the active phase is indicated by:

options.text: Cervical dilatation plotted on/left of alert line
Dilation plotted on the action line
Dilation plotted to the right of the action line

questions.explanation: Progress on or to the left of the Alert line indicates the cervix is dilating at the expected rate (1 cm/hr). Crossing to the right indicates slow progress.

questions.question: According to older PMTCT guidelines (primary level prophylaxis), what was the standard Nevirapine dose for a woman at the onset of labour?
questions.explanation: Single Dose Nevirapine (sdNVP) protocol was 200mg orally at onset of labor.

questions.question: Which characteristics describe a 'rigid cervix' in cervical dystocia?
questions.explanation: Anatomical rigidity presents as a thin, tight ring that fails to dilate (unyielding), unlike an edematous cervix which is swollen due to obstruction.
questions.hint: Like a tight rubber band that won't stretch.

questions.question: Why is perineal trauma common in 'Face to Pubis' (Persistent Occipito-Posterior) delivery?
questions.explanation: In Face to Pubis delivery, the head is born by flexion but presents with the larger Occipito-Frontal diameter (11.5cm) instead of the smaller Sub-occipito-bregmatic (9.5cm), stretching the perineum more.
questions.hint: A larger diameter of the head sweeps the perineum.

questions.question: When does the functional closure of the Ductus Arteriosus typically occur?
questions.explanation: Functional closure occurs within the first 10-15 hours after birth due to rising Oxygen tension.

questions.question: What is the specific anti-opioid drug used in newborn resuscitation for respiratory depression caused by maternal narcotics?
questions.explanation: Naloxone (Narcan) reverses opioid-induced respiratory depression.

questions.question: Which anti-infective factor is abundant in human milk but absent in cow's milk?
questions.explanation: Lysozyme is an enzyme that destroys bacterial cell walls and is found in high concentrations in breast milk (300x cow's milk).

questions.question: Injury to the fetal scalp caused by pressure from the cervix (girdle of contact) is called:
questions.explanation: Caput succedaneum is edema of the scalp caused by obstructed venous return at the girdle of contact (cervix). It crosses suture lines.

questions.question: Match the PPH causes to their management:
questions.explanation: Atony -> Massage. Retained -> Remove. Tear -> Stitch. Coagulopathy -> Replace factors.

questions.question: Which of the following are exogenous causes of puerperal infection?
questions.explanation: Exogenous organisms come from outside sources (attendants, environment). Strep and Staph are classic exogenous pathogens. E. coli is endogenous.

questions.question: A Para 6+0 mother at 6 weeks postnatal demands BTL (Tubal Ligation). What is the immediate nursing action?
questions.explanation: Before any permanent method, pregnancy must be ruled out (even if amenorrheic). Then appropriate counseling and provision follow.

questions.question: Match the uterine fundal height to the gestation week:
questions.explanation: 12w = Pubis. 24w = Umbilicus. 36w = Peak height.

questions.question: Select the correct layers of the Myometrium:
questions.explanation: The middle oblique layer forms the 'living ligatures' that stop bleeding.

questions.question: Arrange the sequence of the Milk Ejection (Let-down) Reflex:
questions.explanation: Suckling -> Nerve impulse -> Brain -> Oxytocin -> Contraction -> Milk.

questions.question: Differentiate between Cord Presentation and Cord Prolapse:

pairs.right: Cord in front of head, Membranes INTACT
Cord in front of head, Membranes RUPTURED

questions.explanation: The key difference is the status of the membranes. Intact = Presentation (occult). Ruptured = Prolapse (overt emergency).
questions.hint: It depends on whether the waters have broken.

questions.question: Which of the following are signs of Uterine Rupture?

options.text: Easily palpable fetal parts under skin

questions.explanation: When the uterus ruptures, the resistance stops (contractions stop), the baby may float into the abdomen (palpable), and the mother bleeds internally (shock).
questions.hint: The labor stops abruptly and pain becomes constant.

questions.question: Order the stages of an Eclamptic Fit:
questions.explanation: Warning -> Stiffness (Tonic) -> Jerking (Clonic) -> Unconsciousness (Coma).
